title: Brave George Alagiah says he's not afraid to die after more than 40 rounds of chemo
text:

George Alagiah has said he is “not scared to die” after enduring more than 40 rounds of chemotherapy.

The veteran BBC news presenter was first diagnosed with bowel cancer in 2014 and revealed in December 2017 that the disease had returned.

He said: “I’m not actually scared of death. I’m not, for myself. That much I know and I’ve had to work through it in my head.

“I’m one scan away from perhaps knowing that thing is going to happen sooner rather than later.

“I’ve dealt with it for myself, but I do find it very difficult when I think of my loved ones and particularly for the woman who has loved me, and I’ve loved, since 1976 – Frances.”

(Image: Getty Images)

The 63-year-old has two sons, Adam and Matthew, with wife Frances, who he met at Durham University. He also became a grandfather for the first time last year, which he describes as “a wonderful thing”.

After his initial diagnosis nearly six years ago, the disease spread to his liver and lymph nodes.

That needed treatment with 17 rounds of chemotherapy and five operations, including one to remove most of his liver. George returned to work in 2015 but had to take more time out in 2017, when he was told that his bowel cancer had returned.

He explained: “I’m pretty content, strange as it may sound. More so since I was diagnosed with cancer five and a half years ago. Cancer is a physical disease, but you have to deal with it as much in your mind as anywhere else.

(Image: BBC News & Current Affairs via Getty Images)

“You certainly have to come to terms with it. I was in ‘sort your affairs’ territory. It took me three to six months to figure out how I was going to deal with it. I drew up list of good things and bad things in my life – and I discovered the good things way outnumber the bad things,” he said on the How To Fail with Elizabeth Day podcast.

“I’m at chemo tomorrow and various other sorts of treatment, and some of it has been tough.

“Cancer is knocking on my door every day. I have to accept and own that vulnerability, and not let it engulf me.”

(Image: BBC)

Speaking about the gender pay gap at the Beeb, the newsreader, who was named as one of the £250,000 to £300,000 earners, added: “There is a gender pay gap. I know we published a list for us ‘top people’, if you can call us that.

“I am actually more worried about the gender gap below, of the people who don’t get published and whether there is a gap there, and there shouldn’t be.

“It does concern me. I think equal pay for equal work.”
description: The veteran BBC news presenter was diagnosed with bowel cancer in 2014 and the disease returned in 2017
